perturbation.original_text: (t) "Derivative Works" (i) with respect to copyrightable works shall have the meaning set forth in the U.S. Copyright Act, 17 U.S.C. §101, et seq. (including translation into other computer language and any other form in which an existing work may be recast, transformed or adapted which would constitute a derivative work under the U.S. Copyright Act, 17 U.S.C. §101), and (ii) with respect to Know-How, it shall also mean any material derived from such Know-How.
perturbation.changed_text: (t) "Derivative Works" (i) with respect to copyrightable works shall have the meaning set forth in the company's internal guidelines, which may or may not align with the U.S. Copyright Act, 17 U.S.C. §101, et seq. (including translation into other computer language and any other form in which an existing work may be recast, transformed or adapted which would constitute a derivative work under the U.S. Copyright Act, 17 U.S.C. §101), and (ii) with respect to Know-How, it shall also mean any material derived from such Know-How.
perturbation.explanation: The original definition of "Derivative Works" for copyrightable works directly references the U.S. Copyright Act. The modified version introduces ambiguity by stating that the meaning could also be defined by the company's internal guidelines, which creates a legal contradiction. The phrase 'may or may not align with the U.S. Copyright Act' directly contradicts the reliance on established legal definitions.

perturbation.original_text: (jjj) "Object Code" means one or more computer instructions in machine readable form (whether or not packaged in directly executable form), including any such instructions that are readable in a virtual machine, whether or not derived from Source Code, together with any partially compiled or intermediate code that may result from the compilation, assembly or interpretation of any Source Code. Object Code includes firmware, compiled or interpreted programmable logic, libraries, objects, bytecode, machine code, and middleware.
perturbation.changed_text: (jjj) "Object Code" means one or more computer instructions in machine readable form, as further defined and delineated by the Seller in a non-public annex. The definition may include or exclude certain types of code at Seller's discretion, regardless of whether the code is directly executable or derived from Source Code. This definition supersedes any generally accepted definition of Object Code.
perturbation.explanation: This change provides a conflicting definition of "Object Code" where the seller has the right to unilaterally modify the definition as needed. This deviation from established legal and industry norms creates uncertainty about what qualifies as 'Object Code', creating enforceability issues.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Industry standard definitions and interpretations of Object Code within software licensing and intellectual property law.

perturbation.original_text: (xxxx) "Trademarks" means (i) trademarks, service marks, logos, product numbers, trade dress, trade names, corporate names and Internet domain names, slogans, and 11 other indicia of commercial source or origin (whether registered, common law, statutory, or otherwise, and together with all translations thereof), (ii) all registrations and applications to register the foregoing anywhere in the world (including all renewals in connection therewith), and (iii) all goodwill symbolized by any of the foregoing clauses (i) and (ii).
perturbation.changed_text: (xxxx) "Trademarks" means (i) trademarks, service marks, logos, product numbers, trade dress, trade names, corporate names and Internet domain names, slogans, and 11 other indicia of commercial source or origin (only those with federal registration), (ii) all registrations and applications to register the foregoing anywhere in the world (including all renewals in connection therewith), and (iii) all goodwill symbolized by any of the foregoing clauses (i) and (ii).
perturbation.explanation: By restricting the definition of "Trademarks" to 'only those with federal registration', the modified text creates a direct contradiction. The change excludes trademarks that are established via 'common law' or 'statutory' rights that do not require federal registration for protection.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Common law trademark rights, state trademark statutes, and the Lanham Act (15 U.S.C. § 1114)
